title: Create a Simple Box with Fillet
description: Learn to create a basic box shape and add fillets to the edges. This is a fundamental CAD exercise.

steps.title: Start a New Sketch
steps.instruction: Click on the XY plane in the browser or viewport to create a new sketch.
steps.detailedText: Sketches are 2D drawings that define the profile of your 3D shapes. The XY plane (also called the 'Origin' plane) is a good starting point because it's at the center of your design space. Starting here makes it easier to add features symmetrically later.

qcChecks.text: Sketch is created on the XY plane
You are now in sketch editing mode

warnings.text: If you select a different plane, your orientation will be different

visualStep.caption: Click Create Sketch in the toolbar, then select the XY plane

steps.title: Draw a Rectangle
steps.instruction: Select the Rectangle tool (R) and draw a 50mm x 30mm rectangle centered at the origin.
steps.detailedText: Using the Center Rectangle tool ensures your shape is symmetrical around the origin. This is important for many design patterns, especially when you need to add symmetric features or when the part interfaces with other components.

warnings.text: Make sure to use the Center Rectangle, not the 2-Point Rectangle

steps.title: Finish the Sketch
steps.instruction: Click 'Finish Sketch' in the toolbar or press Escape to exit sketch mode.
steps.detailedText: Finishing the sketch locks in your 2D geometry and prepares it for 3D operations. Always finish your sketch before adding extrusions or other features. An unfinished sketch can cause unexpected behavior.

qcChecks.text: Sketch is fully constrained (shown in black)

steps.title: Extrude the Rectangle
steps.instruction: Select the Extrude tool (E), click on the rectangle profile, and set the distance to 20mm.
steps.detailedText: Extrusion takes your 2D sketch profile and pulls it into the third dimension. The 20mm height creates a box that's proportional to the base. Think about what this part will be used for - taller might be stronger, shorter might save material.

requires.reason: The Extrude tool is located in the Solid modeling environment

qcChecks.text: Direction is symmetric or one-sided as intended

warnings.text: Check the direction - the arrow should point away from the plane

visualStep.caption: Select Extrude from the Create dropdown, then click the sketch profile

steps.title: Add Fillets to Top Edges
steps.instruction: Select the Fillet tool (F), then select the four top edges of the box. Set the radius to 3mm.
steps.detailedText: Fillets round off sharp edges. This is important for: 1) Safety - rounded edges are less likely to cut you, 2) Strength - sharp corners concentrate stress and are more likely to crack, 3) Manufacturability - many processes like injection molding require rounded corners.

requires.reason: The Fillet tool is located in the Solid modeling environment

warnings.text: If the fillet fails, try a smaller radius
Radius cannot exceed half the smallest edge dimension

visualStep.caption: Select Fillet from the Modify dropdown, then select the edges to round

fusionActions.message: Select the top edges to fillet

steps.title: Review Your Model
steps.instruction: Rotate the view to inspect all sides of your completed box.
steps.detailedText: Always review your model from multiple angles before considering it complete. Check that all edges are properly filleted, dimensions look correct, and there are no unexpected artifacts. This habit will help you catch errors early.

steps.title: Congratulations!
steps.instruction: You have completed the basic box tutorial. Your model is ready for further modifications or export.
steps.detailedText: You've learned the fundamental CAD workflow: Sketch -> Extrude -> Modify. These same steps apply to almost every 3D model you'll create. Try experimenting with different dimensions, adding chamfers instead of fillets, or creating a hole in the top face.
